<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 215, 388, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 7 Probability & Statistics 2 (S2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 320, 390, 337]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 367, 722, 383]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 384, 325, 400]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 447, 284, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 462, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 589, 509]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 509, 606, 525]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 540, 606, 555]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 556, 756, 572]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 572, 440, 587]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 588, 907, 619]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 92, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 84, 648, 212]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 230, 920, 265]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the graph of the probability density function, f, of a random variable \(X\). Find the median of \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 247, 920, 265]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 292, 92, 310]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 291, 920, 388]]<|/det|>
The heights of a certain type of plant have a normal distribution. When the plants are grown without fertilizer, the population mean and standard deviation are \(24.0 \text{cm}\) and \(4.8 \text{cm}\) respectively. A gardener wishes to test, at the \(2\%\) significance level, whether Hiergro fertilizer will increase the mean height. He treats 150 randomly chosen plants with Hiergro and finds that their mean height is \(25.0 \text{cm}\). Assuming that the standard deviation of the heights of plants treated with Hiergro is still \(4.8 \text{cm}\), carry out the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 373, 920, 390]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 416, 94, 434]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 415, 920, 465]]<|/det|>
The cost of hiring a bicycle consists of a fixed charge of 500 cents together with a charge of 3 cents per minute. The number of minutes for which people hire a bicycle has mean 142 and standard deviation 35.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 478, 151, 496]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 477, 848, 497]]<|/det|>
Find the mean and standard deviation of the amount people pay when hiring a bicycle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 478, 920, 496]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 509, 151, 527]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 508, 920, 543]]<|/det|>
6 people hire bicycles independently. Find the mean and standard deviation of the total amount paid by all 6 people.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 526, 920, 543]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 570, 94, 588]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 570, 920, 620]]<|/det|>
A cereal manufacturer claims that \(25\%\) of cereal packets contain a free gift. Lola suspects that the true proportion is less than \(25\%\). In order to test the manufacturer's claim at the \(5\%\) significance level, she checks a random sample of 20 packets.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 632, 153, 651]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 632, 437, 651]]<|/det|>
Find the critical region for the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 632, 920, 651]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 663, 153, 682]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 663, 507, 682]]<|/det|>
Hence find the probability of a Type I error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 663, 920, 682]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 694, 578, 713]]<|/det|>
Lola finds that 2 packets in her sample contain a free gift.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 725, 151, 744]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 725, 578, 744]]<|/det|>
State, with a reason, the conclusion she should draw.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 725, 920, 744]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 620, 92]]<|/det|>
A random variable \(X\) has probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 98, 620, 153]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}\frac{k}{x - 1} & 3\leqslant x\leqslant 5,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}, \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 157, 293, 175]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 186, 156, 205]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 184, 316, 212]]<|/det|>
Show that \(k = \frac{1}{\ln 2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 191, 920, 210]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 227, 156, 244]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 225, 428, 244]]<|/det|>
Find \(a\) such that \(\mathrm{P}(X < a) = 0.75\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 227, 920, 245]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 272, 96, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 272, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
In order to obtain a random sample of people who live in her town, Jane chooses people at random from the telephone directory for her town.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 319, 153, 337]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 318, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
Give a reason why Jane's method will not give a random sample of people who live in the town.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 335, 920, 354]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 365, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
Jane now uses a valid method to choose a random sample of 200 people from her town and finds that 38 live in apartments.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 413, 151, 431]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 412, 920, 446]]<|/det|>
Calculate an approximate \(99\%\) confidence interval for the proportion of all people in Jane's town who live in apartments.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 428, 920, 446]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 458, 151, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 457, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
Jane uses the same sample to give a confidence interval of width 0.1 for this proportion. This interval is an \(x\%\) confidence interval. Find the value of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 476, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 521, 96, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 520, 517, 540]]<|/det|>
A random variable \(X\) has the distribution \(\mathrm{Po}(1.6)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 552, 153, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 551, 823, 570]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(R\) is the sum of three independent values of \(X\). Find \(\mathrm{P}(R < 4)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 551, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 583, 153, 601]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 581, 789, 601]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(S\) is the sum of \(n\) independent values of \(X\). It is given that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 606, 601, 628]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{P}(S = 4) = \frac{16}{3}\times \mathrm{P}(S = 2).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 635, 218, 653]]<|/det|>
<form>Find \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 635, 920, 653]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 666, 153, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 666, 813, 685]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(T\) is the sum of 40 independent values of \(X\). Find \(\mathrm{P}(T > 75)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 666, 920, 685]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
